messageBody:
Hi David,

Thank you for the quick reply :)

I have added some comments to your original message below.

Best regards,
-Alex.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@...> wrote:
>
> Alex,
>
> Thanks for letting us know. JUnit 4.4 does include method annotations
> in the Description, which should help one of your frustrations.

I'll take a look at the annotation. Thanks for the pointer.
Unfortunately, I'm stuck with JUnit 4.3.1.

> Were you using the default JUnit that ships with Eclipse (currently
4.3.1)?

Yep, I'm using JUnit 4.3.1 that comes with Eclipse.

>
> It sounds like you also wanted to allow users to register a listener
> regardless of how the tests were run, which TestNG does with a
> command-line parameter, and JUnit currently does not support. This
> sounds like a valuable feature--is a command-line parameter the ideal
> way to do it?

A command-line parameter would be very helpful. I'm currently limited
by Eclipse's JUnit plug-in (TestNG Eclipse plug-in allows me to
specify listeners.) It would be nice to somehow register a listener
programatically (not sure if this is a good idea.)

>
> The default runners for JUnit classes should be out of "internal"
> status soon.

That would be really nice and helpful.

> We focused first on making it possible to run any
> conceivable set of tests from JUnit, especially crazy stuff (such as
> Ruby tests: http://johlrogge.wordpress.com/2007/09/08/hybrid-theory/).
> A major focus of 4.5 is making it easier to make finer-grained
> extensions to JUnit's built-in runners, without touching internals.
>
> One more favor--can you explain how FEST currently was capturing
> screenshots from JUnit, and why that didn't work when running tests
> from Eclipse?

Currently, we are taking screenshots (using AWT Robot) by extending
Ant's JUnit report task. We started to extend JUnit itself because a
user (of FEST) needed to take screenshots when a test executed inside
Eclipse fails. I'm not saying that extending JUnit didn't work, it was
just frustrating. I made uncomfortable to depend on internal APIs and
deprecaded code.

>
> Thanks again,
>
> David Saff
>
